results.title: Islands in the sky
results.creator_credit: Dietmar Fill, Klaus Jaritz, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Shows the summer wildflowers in Kosciusko National Park. Discusses adaptation of the plants to the hostile environment and includes an alpine herb field, ferns and bogs.

results.title: The Living forest
results.creator_credit: Tom Morrison, David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson and Victorian Forests Commission
results.brief_description: A film which shows how man is making heavy demands on the earth’s remaining forests. A detailed study is made of the ecology of a eucalypt forest and the many plants and animals which make up the forest environment.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tom Morrison, David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson and Victorian Forests Commission

results.title: The Wetlands problem
results.creator_credit: David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson, Australian Academy of Science and Educational Media Australia
results.brief_description: A case study of the Murray Darling River system which examines man’s relationship with his environment. Shows how the demands we have placed on this important river system for navigation, irrigation, water supply and recreation, have greatly altered it from its original condition. Poses the question, are we altering the ecology of the wetlands to a point where we may no longer derive the benefits we hope to enjoy from this river system?
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson, Australian Academy of Science and Educational Media Australia

results.title: The Venomous Australians
results.brief_description: A discussion of the various venomous creatures in Australia. Looks at snakes, spiders, and other insects and marine animals.

results.title: Transport today
results.creator_credit: David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson and Education Media Australia
results.brief_description: This film provides a brief survey of modern transport. The film has been produced without commentary, only natural effects, and has been designed as an introduction to the study of transport. The film does not deal with any one aspect in detail but shows a range of examples which makes a good starting point for inquiry.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson and Education Media Australia

results.title: 'Where dead men lie': spotlight the director
results.creator_credit: Chris McGill, Graham Chase, Richard Mason and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Based on the production of “Where dead men lie”, highlighting the role of the director, Keith Gow. This film shows his involvement in screen testing, location shooting, editing and mixing. Suitable for Years 7-12.

results.title: Ned Kelly: paintings by Sidney Nolan
results.creator_credit: Tim Burstall, Alan Harkness, Patrick Ryan and Eltham Films

results.title: Roar culture
results.brief_description:
‘Roar culture’ is a successful six month community arts project that was documented on video. The project brought together schools, community groups, artists, people from culturally diverse backgrounds and local government, including over 80 students, 10 storytellers, and 14 artists/mentors. ‘Roar culture’ explores issues of identity concerning ethnic, religious & sexual discrimination, cultural diversity and tolerance.
In doing so, it was critical to the process that there was a space for understanding and insight: a space where the many faces and voices which contribute to Bendigo’s historical and contemporary image and identity, were paid attention.
Stage one: the project’s starting point was the narrative or story. Stories from 10 multicultural & indigenous individuals whose memories ranged from the 1930s through to today, from places and countries which hauntingly navigated us to Bendigo. Each told a different story about living in regional Victoria however the threads of isolation, language difficulties, fragmented families and broader cultural or religious differences provided significant links.
Stage two was a mentor program, which furthered the developed the artistic skills of the students through a variety of cultural & arts mediums. These included workshops exploring Aboriginal dance; Japanese movement and theatre; contemporary and traditional music from a cross section of cultures; photojournalism and visual art mediums.
Stage three included a series of round table discussions and practical workshops uniting the stories of Stage One with the skills development of Stage Two. This enabled scripts & a musical score to be written for the final stage.
Stage four included performance rehearsals & backstage skills development which culminated in an experimental performance through multi-disciplined artforms in the round at The Capital Theatre on July 16 &17 1999.
Participating in this project were students & teachers from Bendigo Senior Secondary College with members of the stage design crew from Girton Grammar School and Catholic College. An original score of music was composed by local musicians and performed by the Bendigo Youth Orchestra. Financial partners were City of Greater Bendigo, Festivals Australia, The Myer Foundation & Victorian Multicultural Commission.
‘Roar culture’ was awarded the 1999 Local Government & the Arts Leadership Award for Best Practice Management of a Cultural Project

Lynda Newton
Project & Artistic Director
